supplemental_loading_references.code_or_standard: BS 6399-1 (Loading for buildings â€” Part 1: dead and imposed loads)
used_for: Selecting characteristic imposed (live) loads for floors by occupancy (residential, offices, assembly, corridors, stairs).
Selecting dead load allowances for finishes/partitions when not calculated explicitly.
supplemental_loading_references.how_it_fits_bs8110_worked_examples_scope: BS 8110 is a concrete design code; load values are typically taken from a loading code such as BS 6399, then actions are factored for ULS/SLS and used in BS 8110 member design.

supplemental_loading_references.code_or_standard: BS 6399-2 (Loading for buildings â€” Part 2: wind loads)
used_for: Determining wind actions (pressure/suction) on building frames, slabs/roofs and cladding support members.
Creating lateral load cases for frame analysis prior to BS 8110 member design.
supplemental_loading_references.how_it_fits_bs8110_worked_examples_scope: Use when the worked examples are extended from gravity-only members to full building design where wind governs lateral actions.

supplemental_loading_references.code_or_standard: BS 6399-3 (Loading for buildings â€” Part 3: imposed roof loads)
used_for: Selecting roof imposed loads (maintenance) and, where relevant, snow-related roof loads in BS 6399 methodology.
Combining roof imposed actions with dead loads for roof beams, purlin-supporting members, and roof slabs.
supplemental_loading_references.how_it_fits_bs8110_worked_examples_scope: Use when extending beam/slab examples to roof members (even if roof is not a concrete slab).

supplemental_loading_references.code_or_standard: BS EN 1991-1-1 (Eurocode 1 actions â€” densities, self-weight, imposed loads)
used_for: Modern alternative to BS 6399 in many jurisdictions; provides densities and imposed loads for buildings.
supplemental_loading_references.how_it_fits_bs8110_worked_examples_scope: If your school allows Eurocode actions, you can still design RC members with BS 8110 using EC1 characteristic actions (with careful factor consistency).
